Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Biosocial Responses to Political Invisibility in a Refugee Camp

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Extensive research has shown that a person's political and social status affects his or her physical, economic, and psychological well-being. However, we do not know exactly how this happens or particularly, how these different factors work together. In the United States and around the world, marginalized populations find ways to directly or indirectly access mainstream socio-economic resources. In the context of unprecedented global population mobility, there is a need to better understand the negative health and psychosocial impacts of low status, especially with respect to their effects on the economy at large. The research funded by this award will address this problem by examining a case in which people suddenly experience a very sharp reduction in their political and social status, which will allow the researchers to observe the effects more clearly. In addition, the research will test the idea that a person's social support networks moderate the effects of low status on well-being. This project will also contribute to an ongoing partnership between the co-PIs, economic development practitioners at the World Bank, humanitarian aid officials at the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), and health service providers from the International Rescue Committee. Data and analyses from this project will be shared with these policy makers to continue to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of refugee-oriented projects in a variety of global contexts.

Notre Dame anthropology doctoral student Rieti Gengo, under the supervision of Dr. Rahul Oka and Dr. Lee T. Gettler, will carry out the research at the Kakuma Refugee Camp in northern Kenya. With approximately 200,000 residents, Kakuma is one of the world's largest refugee camps. Thousands of asylum seekers at Kakuma lose institutional support from the UNHCR and other international non-governmental organizations when their petitions for refugee status are rejected, denying them access to food distribution, healthcare resources, and other services. Those denied refugee status are expected to leave the camp, but most are unable to do so because of prohibitive financial costs and their precarious status as stateless persons. The unfortunate situation provides an important research opportunity to compare the effects of marginality on those who receive official status and those who do not. The researchers will collect data on how both groups obtain resources and how their social and behavioral responses are reflected in their health and physiology. They will employ ethnographic participant observation, semi-structured interviews, and the World Health Organization Quality of Life questionnaire to assess refugees' perceived wellbeing and integration into the camp's informal economy. They will collect social network data to quantify the size and diversity of social support networks. Body composition (body fat and BMI), blood pressure, and heart rate will be used to provide measures of overall health and nutritional status, while biomarkers of immune function and stress physiology will be assessed from blood and fingernail samples. Findings from this research will provide insight into the behavioral and physiological pathways through which low-status, marginalized populations cope with exclusion from institutional resources and services.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite the humanitarian ideal that refugees should be passive recipients of aid, refugees at Kakuma Refugee Camp, Kenya, actively engage in complex economic behaviors to derive a sense of normalcy in their daily lives. This dissertation project takes a biosocial perspective on refugee agency under institutional constraint, in order to better understand how the politically invisible might avoid the expected psychosocial and health impacts of their position through active social reorganization. As politically invisible populations (e.g., undocumented migrants, illicit sex workers, stateless persons) continue to grow in number and socio-economic contribution globally, there is a crucial need to understand the various means of adaptation and resilience utilized by such economically significant populations, as well as the combined impact of their status and adaptation on the general social economy. This dissertation project has two primary aims: (1) to identify pathways between political invisibility and its psychosocial, economic, and physiological outcomes; and (2) to examine the extent to which social networking behavior acts as an adaptive moderator in these pathways.

This research directly addresses several current anthropological themes. Primarily, it examines the political economy of poverty and political invisibility among refugees at Kakuma using computational methods, including Social Network Analysis and Structural Equation Modeling. The ethnographically contextualized network approach conceptualizes resilience as an emergent biosocial property of cooperative behavior, and contributes to knowledge about human social and physiological adaptability under conditions of structural violence and social regulation. It also unpacks some of the complexity of behavioral mechanisms through which agents enact resilience within adverse structural conditions. Specifically, we use quantitative network measures to empirically test whether characteristics of social support systems can account for variation in health and stress. We also identify a suite of testable indicators of resilience, including the proposed social network mechanism, that will likely improve our understanding of how and why some people thrive and others wither under the same conditions. 

This research is of interest to multiple non-governmental organizations engaged in humanitarian aid and development work in Kenya. Stakeholders representing the UNHCR have expressed the potential of this research to provide the empirical basis for improving the quality of, and access to, mental health care for refugees in Kakuma. PI Oka and co-PI Gengo have also been working alongside teams from the World Bank to expand opportunities for refugees and members of the Turkana host community to own and operate businesses in Kakuma, and this research project will contribute key insights into refugee political economy to aid in that effort. In addition to training a PhD student at the University of Notre Dame (co-PI Gengo), this dissertation project has successfully established an interdisciplinary, inter-institutional collaboration between three universities. The project also provided training in ethnographic and anthropometric research methods to a Kenyan student undertaking a bachelor?s degree in development studies. Additionally, it provided temporary employment to five refugees in Kakuma, who acted as translators and/or research assistants.
